# What I’ve Learned: An Experience with Microblogging

## My recent exploration into Twitter (by promoting this blog) has given me an
insight into using the platform as a ‘microblog’. But what exactly is a
microblog, what has the experience taught me, and why is it so great?

Journalism 365

·

Follow

6 min read

·

Dec 20, 2019

\--

Listen

Share

Microblogging: a recent term that encompasses the use of social media sites to
make **short, frequent posts** — effectively small (micro) blog posts. The
name really is self explanatory.

> “ Microblogging is a combination of blogging and instant messaging that
> allows users to create short messages to be posted and shared with an
> audience online.” Daniel Nations

Platforms such as Twitter have become more and more popular for supporting
**new phenomena and mediums such as microblogs.**

Photo by NeONBRAND on Unsplash

With 330 million monthly users, posting content across social media like
Twitter in **shorter, more digestible chunks** makes your information likely
to actually be taken in by your audience, and it’s by far **easier to
communicate** over these mediums.

The trend emerged thanks to the **merge of blogging and social media** ,
allowing people to publish in a way that is faster in keeping people informed
with **relevant, shareable content** , and an easier mode of communication.

# How are Microblogs Presented?

The content that is shared on a microblog can take almost any form; **text,
video, images, hyperlinks and audio.**

Here are some common sites used for microblogs:

  *  **Twitter** : as mentioned before, Twitter is a common microblogging site. Limited to 280 character ‘tweets’ users can present their content through text, images, video or hyperlinks.
  *  **Tumblr** : more popular in the late 2000s to early 2010s, Tumblr is perhaps slightly more aligned with the common blogging site with third party widgets and applications allowing users to customise their site. Content is also shareable in a variety of forms, and common interaction buttons also apply to this site, making it quicker once more to share the content you come across.
  *  **Instagram** : Instagram is the photo form of a microblog. It allows you to constantly keep people up to date with what you’re doing by uploading photos one by one. Pictures can also be captioned to allow for even more detail and a link back to traditional blogging.

Photo by Sincerely Media on Unsplash

# My Microblogging Experience

My recent experience with microblogging has taught me a lot about the
practice.

If you’re not following me on Twitter, I’ve been **sharing my posts** on this
site, **sharing and commenting on other works** on similar topics and
**starting discussions** with people via engaging with their content through
replies or retweets.

I’ve been able to draw people to my own site through **establishing myself as
a source of information** , but I’ve provided this information in short
snippets that have (hopefully!) caught people’s attention.

Our attention span as a species is declining. Take a look at some of these
statistics if you don’t agree:

Credit: Wyzowl [https://www.wyzowl.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Human-
Attention-Span-1.png]

As you can see, users don’t tend to look at webpages for very long.

Microblogging has been a great experience for me as it’s allowed me to **share
information in a variety of different forms** at a pace the reader enjoys and
engages with the most.

# Personalisation

Microblogging has become even more important with the introduction of
**personalised feeds.**

These could be feeds on social media, or even personalised news feed. You can
**choose who you follow, who you engage with, and who’s content you see.**

The chances of content showing up in newsfeeds becomes less and less,
therefore **competition rises more** — and in turn, users will choose to
engage with the content that **says the most in the least words** — such as
that present in microblogs.

# Why is Microblogging so Great?

Both from industry knowledge and my own experiences of microblogging, I’ve
developed a list of the **best things about microblogging:**

  *  **Spending Less Time Creating Content** — since you’re creating smaller snippets of content, it won’t take you hours to write a post on a microblog like it might an ordinary blog.
  *  **Easier Digestion of Content** — people are more likely to take notice of smaller pieces of content and remember them than they are longer content. Smaller snippets are easier to digest, process and understand.
  *  **Catching Reader Attention** — you can use added features like GIFS, photos, video to catch reader attention — often these will take up most of the space of a tweet, so they’re a great addition to include.
  *  **Frequency of Content Shared** — content can be shared at all times of day pretty much non stop. This is great for updating certain situations e.g. news and current events like debates or catastrophe.
  *  **Sharing Straight Away** — there’s no need to wait for a publishing team or for anything to be printed, the content you share on a microblog simply needs to be proofread and then can be shared instantly, often making microblogging sites some of the first to break important news.
  *  **Engagement and Community** — since a lot of people tend to write on the same news or topics, you can find yourself a community on microblogging sites. These accounts will often comment on each others’ work and share similar content.
  *  **Mobile Convenience** — Twitter is far better as a mobile site, as are a lot of other microblogging sites. This allows for creating on the go!

# What Have I Gained?

Microblogging has taught me the skills to **present news in a variety of
different forms.**

For example, when sharing my blog posts, I had to ensure I included a snippet
of the content that described enough of the blog post to **catch people’s
attention, but within a character limit.**

It has also taught me further to read a whole article and **comment on the
most prominent details**. For example, when commenting via retweet on other
Tweets, I’ve only 280 characters to sum up my opinion and start a discussion.
Microblogging has, therefore, taught me even further to **read with an
analytical eye** and challenge myself to **find the best language to sum up my
findings.**

Photo by Kon Karampelas on Unsplash

Overall, my experience with microblogging has further developed a lot of the
skills I have gained during my time at university, but also challenged me in
terms of expressing myself within a smaller character count and helped me to
**be more articulate with the specific language I use.**

One element that was incredibly difficult, which many may not have expected
considering I’m from a generation who has grown up with the internet, was
**being online often enough.**

On numerous occasions I found myself sat thinking **‘what could I be
commenting on now’** when completing other tasks. There’s such a wealth of
information shared on platforms like Twitter, that even taking a couple of
hours in the day off can mean you **miss out on important snippets of
information.**

When this did happen, I would ensure to **set time aside the next time I was
online** to find and comment on some quality content to make up for the time I
had missed!
